tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Fragment in Ogden's hand. Reporting the absence of material witnesses for trial of Jalbert. And postponement of case until next term. He has no doubt witnesses were Spirited away.

tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: A.L.S. Enclosing copy of letter addressed by him to General Commanding in Chief. Best spirit prevails in townships on river St. Clair which he visited. Few instances of disaffection have appeared in that section. Inclines to belief that information obtained by local government as to encouragement held out to American gangs on United States frontier cannot be relied upon.

A.L.S. Returned from Montreal the day before. Enquiries made by him as to state of feeling in Upper Canada are reassuring. Sandom directed to have gun-boat and 2 pinnaces stationed at Sandwich. He received many courtesies from authorities of Detroit. Enclosed letter from Macomb indicates subsidence of excitement on American side. Transmitting letter from Mr. Moffatt on subject of union of provinces. (No enclosure.)
Private. A.L.S. Thanks for copies of despatches, His remarks sent to Couper.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY

tagDescription: Directions given by Sir Charles Paget to Captain Harvey of the Malabar respecting the disposition of that portion of navy which he is leaving at Quebec, after his own departure. Copy.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Enclosures: (2) Deposition of William McGouin, as to conspiracy to destroy loyal inhabitants.

Enclosure: Copy. Enclosing letter from Lieut. Col. Williams. Information as to passing of arms into province. Inhabitants of St. Johns desire to form small independent corps, and ask to be furnished with arms, which he recommends.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY

tagDescription: A.L.S. Has been notified by Glenelg that no officer has been appointed to succeed him, in the expectation that, if he understood the inconvenience of relieving him, he would consent to stay. He will therefore stay.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: A.L.S. Enclosing two letters. one from Chaffers, the other from the Curé of St. Césaire. Has been informed on best authority that not less than 600 Patriots have crossed the line to put themselves in communication with Dr. Coté.
Enclosure: Return.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY

tagDescription: Unsigned communication in French, as to existence and plans of conspirators in Upper and Lower Canada.

A.L.S. Stating that she and Miss Chandler had waited on Arthur at Coteau du Lae, and presented letter given them by Couper, but that Arthur could give no assurance that Wait and Chandler would be reprieved.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Enclosures: (2) Copy. Forwarding stores.

Enclosures: (2) Copy. Enclosing letter addressed to him by Clitherow containing account of attack about to be made on Isle aux Noix. Information he receives as to agitation among British Canadians is prospect of General rising among French Canadians. Preparations he is making.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY

tagDescription: Sub-enclosure: A.L.S. and copy. Capture of two cannon concealed in waggon and cart.

Private and confidential. A.L.S. Account of secret meetings of conspirators in vicinity of Isle aux Noix. The oaths taken. Information obtained from two person of highest respectability, who divulged secrets from religious motives.

THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: L.S. Respecting opinion of Attorney General as to seamen in jail, who have volunteered for navy. As opinion does not appear to oppose his application for the liberation of seamen, he makes formal application in that sense.

A.L.S. Enclosing deposition of John Smith, and copy of section of United States Act, in connection with removal of gun from Swanton. Has given direction for all vehicles moving at unusual hour to be examined. Communication with American officers respecting the gun purported to have been stolen from Swanton.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Copy, with draft corrected by Buller. Discussion of Act of William IV. 1835, respecting Seamen. The only authority that could release seamen from prison to enter the navy is the Governor General, and he would not be disposed to exercise his authority. As regards seamen imprisoned for offences committed on shore, the sentences must take their course, but the keeper of the jail would furnish list of seamen under his charge with dates of expiration of sentence.

tagDescription: Copy. Expressing apprehension that attack on St. Johns is meditated, and asking for increase in military force.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: L.S. Giving the result of his enquiries into arrest of Mr. Davidson at Fort Covington. British Government cannot interfere at present stage, as the action taken against Davidson is a private one, of which United States Government cannot take cognizance. When United States Courts decide that British Government has no authority to sanction acts done on British territory, it will then be proper to interfere. He has assured Davidson that, should it appear that the proceedings are taken on ground of actions done legally as a British subject, the Government will fully indemnify him. The proceeding is a singular perversion of the civil law.
Enclosures: (2) L.S. Measures taken to prevent trouble on frontier.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Enclosures: (2) A.L.S. In French. Evidences of conspiracy among loyal inhabitants.

Confidential. A.L.S. Respecting command in Canada. Will do his best to promote Durham's wishes respecting Sir Colin Campbell, whom he highly commends. Has been observing course of events in Canada. Glad to notice that Durham will complete his work before his departure.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Enclosures: (4) Copy. Approval of his action, though he himself is one of the incredulous, and attaches little importance to Taylor's report.
Deposition of G. D. Potter of Clarenceville, as to information received by him on steamer Burlington, indicating plans for general rising in Richelieu district. Copy.

tagDescription: Enclosures: (3) A.L.S. Dangerous condition of his district. Loyal inhabitants in dread of murderous rising of disaffected. Urgent need for reinforcements.

THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: A.L.S. Stating in reply to enquiry of 21st that he would not feel justified in relinquishing command until regularly relieved. Should Durham maintain his determination to return to England, he is prepared to take harness again. General lack of confidence in security of province.

tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Enclosures: (1) Copy. Stating circumstances under which he despatched a detachment to strengthen the force at Isle aux Noix. General belief among English on frontiers that some sudden rising is contemplated. Many meetings of Canadian refugees being held at Champlain. They visit Coté and Gagnon.

Enclosures: (1) A.L.S. His enquiries convince him of correctness of information already furnished: secret oaths are being administered to habitants at nocturnal meetings of persons inimical to Government. Evil extending to adjoining parishes.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY

tagDescription: A.D.C. Copy. Enclosing letter from Lieut. Col. Williams, stating that only one gun was captured at Moore's Corner, instead of two as first reported.

tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 2. LETTERS AND DESPATCHES FROM LORD DURHAM TO COLONIAL SECRETARY AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE GOVERNMENT. VOLUME I
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: A.L.S. Tranquility being completely restored, and Sandom having been provided with means required to establish commanding position on lakes, he proposes to turn attention to other parts of his command. Expressions of gratitude for Durham's unvarying goodwill. His arrangements.

A.L.S. True bills obtained against Jalbert, Maillet, Pratte and Louis Lussier for murder of Weir; no bill against Mignault and J. B. Lussier. Also, true bills against Nicolas, Daunais, two Puissonneault, Garant and Beaulieu for murder of Chartrand; and no bill against Bereassé-first four in jail, Garant and Beaulieu in United States. Trial of Jalbert on Tuesday; foresees his acquittal from manner of witnesses. Murderers of Chartrand to be tried on Thursday.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: A.L.S. Enclosing copy of letter from Clitherow with this reply.

A.L.S. Enclosing copy of letter he has sent to Arthur. Necessary to have another regiment from Nova Scotia. Hears priests much alarmed at proceedings in the parishes. It is vain to attempt to legislate or carry into effect, measures of reform, with province in existing state. Desirability of another regiment for use in Upper Canada. Mass of inhabitants loyal, contented, active and spirited, but unless there is sufficient number of soldiers to protect every part of province, the state of excitement and alarm will prove ruinous. No enclosure.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: Enclosure: Copy. Account of inspection. Same information as to Durham as to loyalty of inhabitants. Much alarm excited which will take time to allay.
Enclosures: (1) Statement not here.
A.L.S. Enclosing statement, which was forwarded to him; also, letter from Forsyth, United States Secretary of State.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY
tagDescription: A.L.S. Conveying to him information as to the formation of a vast organization containing 80,000 members, whose purpose it is to prepare for the invasion of Upper Canada during the following winter. The information was imparted to him by Benjamin Ogden, an eminent lawyer and for many years a leader of the Whig party, for the purpose of transmission to Durham. Mr. Ogden was about to notify the Government in Washington, and assured him that, though opposed to it, he was convinced of the Government's good faith towards Great Britain and of its sincere desire to preserve peace between the two countries. Young, also, relates that the Mayor of New York told him that Papineau had lately visited him and expressed surprise at the inaction of Americans over burning of Caroline. The Mayor stated they were satisfied to leave matters in hand of Government at Washington, and, on Papineau's intimating that he intended to discuss the matter, the Mayor said that if he attempted any public agitation, he would put it down and Papineau along with it.
L.S. Enclosing two letters from Clitherow with enclosures.
tagNotebook: THE DURHAM PAPERS SESSIONAL PAPER No. 23 SECTION 4. POLITICAL DISTURBANCES. NAVAL AND MILITARY

tagDescription: A.L.S. Expressing hope Durham may remain with him on Sunday.
